hints_html:
Recall that the \(n\)-th degree Taylor polynomial \(T_n(x)\) centred at \(x=a\) for a function \(f(x)\) is given by \(T_n(x) = \sum_{i=0}^{n} c_i(x-a)^i\) , where \(c_i\) is a coefficient.

Recall also that the coefficients are given by \(c_i = \frac{f^{(i)}(a)}{i!}\), i.e., \(T_n(x) = \sum_{i=0}^{n} \frac{f^{(i)}(a)}{i!}(x-a)^i\).

sols_html:
By definition of the Taylor polynomials,

\[\begin{aligned} T_2(x) &= \sum_{i=0}^{2} \frac{f^{(i)}(a)}{i!}(x-a)^i \\ &= \frac{f^{(0)}(a)}{0!}(x-a)^0 + \frac{f^{(1)}(a)}{1!}(x-a)^1 + \frac{f^{(2)}(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2 \\ &= f(a) + f'(a)(x-a) + \frac{f''(a)}{2}(x-a)^2\end{aligned}\]

Computing the values of the derivatives of \(f\) at 1, we find that \(f(1) = 4 ,\, f'(1) = 12 ,\, f''(1) = 24\). Therefore

\[\begin{aligned} T_2(x) &= f(a) + f'(a)(x-a) + \frac{f''(a)}{2}(x-a)^2 \\ &= {\color{blue} 4 + 12(x-1) + 12(x-1)^2}\\ &= {\color{blue} 12x^2 - 12x + 4}\end{aligned}\]
